title: How It Played | G.O.P. Bingo Night
content:
Inside two bars showing the debate, some nursed beers and grudges against the Bush family. An organizer of the viewing party brought something else: debate bingo boards, containing expected Republican buzzwords.

“Hillary’s emails,” one square reads.
 
“Trump refers to himself in the third person,” says another.
 
One square appears to give the candidates slightly more credit: “Someone makes a joke that’s actually funny.”

title: The Undercard Verdict: A Fiorina TKO
content: “So, President Fiorina?” That was an exchange in the taco line of the press center after the undercard debate, so consider the sources and take it for what it's worth. Still, by a series of highly imperfect metrics, Carly Fiorina emerged as the candidate who may have done the most for herself in the early-evening debate with Republican primary voters. “They should invite carly fiorina back for the 9 oclock debate,’’ Newt Gingrich, a veteran of the 2012 Republican primary, known for slashing debates, wrote on Twitter. According to Google, searches for Ms. Fiorina surpassed those for Donald J. Trump on Thursday evening. Her crisp remarks and steely demeanor stood out in an often listless 80-minute debate. A former high-tech executive whose only previous political experience was a failed Senate race in California, Ms. Fiorina alluded to her corporate experience in deploring the president's Iran nuclear deal. “Obama broke every rule of negotiation," she said. In another memorable moment, she mocked Mr. Trump for speaking with Bill Clinton before he ran. “I didn’t get a phone call from Bill Clinton before I jumped in the race," she said. Ms. Fiorina did not say much she has not often uttered on the campaign trail, and her all-business, frosty charm was familiar to those who have previously tuned into her. But as one of the freshest figures to a national audience — not to mention the only woman in the Republican field — she stood out when seen for the first time. The same qualities created a mini-Carly wave this spring in Iowa, where she has campaigned aggressively. Several weeks ago, her campaign was boasting that she had enough momentum to make the top 10 candidates for tonight’s events. But she ended up falling back, not least because of Mr. Trump. Many eyes will now be on her to see if she has finally achieved escape velocity.

title: Lindsey Graham to Japan, on Hiroshima: I’d Have Dropped the Bomb, Too
content:
[nytmedia id="100000003841350" crop="592" type="image"]

One of the staples of presidential debates is the presence of foreign reporters in the "spin room" afterward. They enjoy a level of access to the candidates and their aides that is otherwise rarely granted by campaigns that are focused entirely on reaching American voters.

So it was no surprise when, after the opening debate here Thursday night, a pair of Japanese reporters joined the scrum around Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina.

What did offer a bit of a jolt — and, presumably, make for some news back home — was what Mr. Graham said in response to a question about whether America was right, 70 years ago, to drop the atomic bomb on Hiroshima.

“If I were President Truman, I would have dropped the bomb,” said Mr. Graham, not hesitating for a moment. By doing so and avoiding an invasion, he added, many American and Japanese lives were saved.

Then it was back to Donald J. Trump questions.

title: In Fact | Bobby Jindal Overstates His Fiscal Discipline
content: [nytmedia id="100000003841189" crop="592" type="image"] Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana bragged of his fiscal conservatism by touting his record of cutting the state’s budget by 26 percent. “We've cut 26 percent of our budget,” Mr. Jindal said. “We have 30,000 fewer state bureaucrats than the day I took office. I don't think anybody has cut that much government anywhere, at any time.” Mr. Jindal has been making the claim for a while now, but according to FactCheck.org, the governor is overstating his fiscal discipline. According to budget documents, Louisiana used $10 billion less in federal funds from 2008 to 2016, accounting for the 26 percent reduction. In fact, it was smaller hurricane aid appropriations rather than tough cutbacks that were responsible for the budget shrinkage Mr. Jindal mentioned.

title: Lines of Attack
content: The candidates in the 5 p.m. debate focused their attacks on President Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton, rather than their opponents onstage. Of their fellow Republican nominees, the candidates only went after Donald J. Trump after moderators directly asked them for their opinions on him. There may be a different pattern at 9 p.m., when candidates will be allowed 30-second rebuttals if another candidate mentions their name. Line thickness represents the number of attacks.

title: Adding to Debate Drama, Donald Trump’s Plane Is Late to Cleveland
content:
As if there could be any more drama around Donald J. Trump’s appearance at the Republican presidential debate, his private plane got off to a late start this afternoon in its trek to Cleveland.

Mr. Trump’s Boeing 757 arrived in Cleveland about 4:30 p.m., about an hour after its scheduled arrival after it was delayed out of New York’s LaGuardia Airport, according to real-time records from the website flightwise.com.

A spokeswoman, Hope Hicks, confirmed that Mr. Trump was on board his plane. Mr. Trump's surname -- TRUMP -- is emblazoned in gold block letters on the side of the plane. Ms. Hicks would not expand on Mr. Trump's travel.

As Mr. Trump has soared in the polls, the interest in tonight’s debate has risen — with the businessman placed center stage based on his strong polling. Other candidates have been plotting strategies for sparring with Mr. Trump, who was the star of the television show "The Apprentice."

Earlier on Thursday, candidates were posting photos on social media of themselves touring the debate stage Quicken Loans Arena in Cleveland. It was not clear if Mr. Trump's late arrival would hurt his efforts to get settled and prepare for the 9 p.m. debate.

The delays of Mr. Trump's flight appeared consistent with the problems at LaGuardia Airport. The Federal Aviation Administration was noting delays of up to an hour out of the airport.

title: With Donald Trump Center Stage, Debate Could Be Ratings Boon
content: The first Republican presidential debate has the makings of being a television sensation, with Donald J. Trump bringing a burst of unexpected attention to the party's nominating fight. Debates have been growing in popularity and viewership as the political discourse has become increasingly partisan. But debates early in the campaign season often made barely a blip in the airwaves. In May 2007, 10 Republicans gathered in California for an MSNBC debate in which the party was charting its course away from former President George W. Bush. According to data from Nielsen, just 1.7 million people tuned in to watch them take the stage at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library. Four years later, just five Republicans showed up for the first debate of the 2012 race. With several candidates having not yet declared their plans to run, the affair had an undercard feel to it, and The Times reported Reince Priebus, chairman of the Republican National Committee, trying to ease anxiety within the party. “As we all know, there are numerous other candidates that are looking at it — and thank God,” he said. Despite the weak turnout of candidates, that debate, which was sponsored by Fox, drew 3.3 million viewers. With so many Republican candidates this time around, Fox had to limit the stage to the top 10. Of course, with Mr. Trump in the mix — and leading the polls — Mr. Priebus is tempering nerves for other reasons.

title: Debate Night in Cleveland: What the Republican Candidates Need to Do
content: The 10 leading Republican presidential candidates enter Thursday night’s face-off hoping to impress primary voters and contributors, while avoiding the sort of missteps that often make for the most memorable moments of a debate. It is not always evident who has won these debates, but it is often abundantly clear who has lost. Yet in a race with no traditional front-runner, none of the contenders will be able to get by with a “do no harm” approach. Campaigns are rarely decided by a single debate — particularly those held months before any votes are cast. But the Cleveland forum offers the Republicans their first high-profile opportunity to create impressions that could shape the race for weeks or months to come. Each participant has a distinct set of objectives. Here is an analysis of what each must try to accomplish. Donald J. Trump [nytmedia id="100000003839081" crop="592" type="image"] Mr. Trump’s appeal owes no small amount to notions that he represents an unmistakable break from conventional politics. So the usual dictates for presidential debaters — avoid thy gaffe, for one — do not necessarily apply. His supporters will overlook an uninformed answer on a policy question, and they may even applaud an insult that, delivered by someone else, would backfire. Yet even a positively huge coat of Teflon will not protect Mr. Trump from an eventual need to show that he is presidential material. He has proved, in the face of great skepticism, that he can channel the anger some grass-roots Republicans feel toward party leaders as well as their dismay about what they see as America’s decline. Thursday’s debate and those that will follow will help determine if Mr. Trump can take the next step and demonstrate that he has the vision and temperament to turn those raw emotions into a movement. This will require him to act more like a president than a performance artist. Jeb Bush [nytmedia id="100000003839082" crop="592" type="image"] It already verges on cliché, but that does not make it any less true: Mr. Bush must show that he is more Jeb than Bush. A few million viewers with only the vaguest sense of him as anything more than the son and brother of presidents will be getting their first extended look at Mr. Bush, the former governor of Florida. He has repeatedly struggled with questions about his family. So he must come to Cleveland with a concise answer that acknowledges the warm feelings many Republicans have toward the Bushes, while making plain that he is not a mere extension of a dynasty for which others in the party and beyond have little affection. Perhaps more than any other candidate, Mr. Bush also bears the pressure of having to introduce himself while coming prepared to play defense. As the closest thing to an establishment favorite, he will probably face an implied assault, if not a frontal one, from his rivals. How Mr. Bush projects his hopeful, general election-friendly brand of Republicanism while parrying questions about his conservatism will offer insights into his deftness as a candidate. Scott Walker [nytmedia id="100000003839076" crop="592" type="image"] He lacks celebrity or a gilded family name, which makes the early strength Mr. Walker has demonstrated that much more remarkable. Now he must prove to Republicans who like his record as Wisconsin’s governor that he has heft and poise. He has spent months on a foreign policy crash course and will need to show a grasp of issues that could confront a commander-in-chief. Like any candidate who unexpectedly builds a lead or emerges as one of the names to beat, he also has much to lose when the lights come on. Mike Huckabee [nytmedia id="100000003839089" crop="592" type="image"] Mr. Huckabee, the former Arkansas governor and 2008 presidential candidate, faces the prospect of being overtaken by new faces. To compensate, he has lately pushed the rhetorical envelope (and then some). But Mr. Huckabee is never going to out-hyperbolize Mr. Trump. And religious conservatives, not Tea Party activists, are his natural base. He needs to remind evangelicals, especially in Iowa, of what made them fall for him in the first place: his ability to project uncompromising social conservatism with a smile. Ben Carson [nytmedia id="100000003839072" crop="592" type="image"] Conservatives looking for a break from politics as usual love the idea of Mr. Carson, an African-American doctor dispensing what they see as hard truths about the country’s troubles. But he hopes to succeed where a long line of political outsiders who promised to bring a dose of common sense to the process have failed. He must show a command of policy issues to demonstrate his readiness. Critiquing Democrats and society’s ills will keep the book deals coming, but it will not be enough to take him past Iowa. Ted Cruz [nytmedia id="100000003839097" crop="592" type="image"] No other candidate comes with the kind of advanced billing Mr. Cruz has. He starred on his Princeton debate team. But he is not used to being interrupted. With limited time, the Texas senator must quickly demonstrate his political talent, not just his forensic skills, to the conservatives whose support he needs. That means combining the fearlessness of a Trump with the human touches of a Huckabee — and doing so in the hurly-burly of a 10-person debate. Marco Rubio [nytmedia id="100000003839071" crop="592" type="image"] Mr. Trump’s dominance and his own focus on fund-raising kept Mr. Rubio, a Florida senator, out of the headlines for months. For Mr. Rubio, a candidate with considerable gifts as an orator, the debates that start with this first one in Ohio are an opening to prove he belongs near the front of the pack. If Mr. Walker’s objective is inherently defensive — living up to poll numbers — Mr. Rubio must take the initiative and show he has the maturity and policy depth to be in contention. Rand Paul [nytmedia id="100000003839100" crop="592" type="image"] Mr. Paul will be competing for hard-line conservative support, and he must remind more ideologically driven activists why he stands out. If he does so by making the case for a more restrained foreign policy, he will probably be attacked. But if he cogently argues his points without looking indecisive or irritated when pressed, he could rally the many primary voters who share his libertarian leanings. Mr. Paul was already suffering through a difficult summer when the head of his “super PAC” was indicted on Wednesday. Few others on stage need a breakout performance as badly as Mr. Paul. Chris Christie [nytmedia id="100000003839058" crop="592" type="image"] It is no surprise that a pugnacious, New York-area Republican has cast a long shadow over the campaign, but now Mr. Christie must make the case that there is room for two of them. The New Jersey governor should not try to match Mr. Trump’s bombast. But the debate offers Mr. Christie a chance to show voters hungry for authenticity and fearlessness that they have a more responsible option with a cogent policy agenda. Even more than Mr. Rubio, Mr. Christie has faded in recent months. Yet no other candidate this side of Trump Tower is running more on his persona, and, as Newt Gingrich proved in the last campaign, debates offer the best platform for such aspirants to force themselves back into contention. John R. Kasich [nytmedia id="100000003839102" crop="592" type="image"] He was the last candidate to make the prime-time debate, and it is important that he did: The setting in Cleveland offers Mr. Kasich, Ohio’s governor, a chance to trumpet his record in one of the campaign’s most important swing states. It also presents an opportunity to show fickle donors that he is a real threat to Mr. Bush. Yet Mr. Kasich could waste the opportunity by underscoring perceptions that he is hopelessly undisciplined and more than a little prickly. Debates can be unforgiving for candidates with a penchant for wandering into verbal cul-de-sacs. And the need to fight for time, in his own state, with nine other candidates could reveal his abrasiveness.
